Award.AwardTitle: Link homology, cohomological operations, and categorification at roots of unity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to study categorification, a relatively new branch of mathematics that has been successful at lifting previously known objects to new structural levels. This includes transforming combinatorial systems that involve natural numbers into higher-order structures built out of vector spaces whose dimensions are those numbers, while vector spaces themselves lift to categories. Integers are consistently lifted to complexes of vector spaces. Link homology theories constitute such a lift of quantum link invariants. The latter boast deep relations to quantum field theory, statistical mechanics, and many areas of mathematics, and categorifying link homology extends these relations and produces new ones at a higher structural level. The proposal will investigate categorification at roots of unity, which should lead to such structural lifting of the Chern-Simons theory and quantum 3-manifold invariants and, eventually, parts of conformal field theory. The project also aims to enhance and unite recent discoveries of cohomological operations on link homologies. These operations rigidify link homology groups and exhibit connections to algebraic topology; in the latter some of most profound result required studying not just homology groups and their extraordinary counterparts, but entire systems of cohomological operations on them. It is likely that understanding the full algebra of cohomological operations on link homology will significanly advance this subject as well as many areas of mathematics and mathematical physics in its proximity.


The project will investigate categorification and link homology, find cohomological operations that rigidify link homology theories, and advance categorification at roots of unity for quantum groups, their representations, and quantum link and 3-manifold invariants. Known cohomological operations are likely just a small part of much bigger algebras of cohomological operations acting on various link homology theories, in particular, on Khovanov-Rozansky and Webster homology groups. Recent work on categorification of quantum groups at roots of unity points to existence of a deep but undeveloped theory, including an analogue of homological algebra where the role of complexes is played by p-complexes. One of the project's goals is to categorify the Jones polynomial and other quantum link invariants at prime roots of unity by further developing categorification of quantum groups and their representations within the framework of p-complexes and hopfological algebra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Categorification is a mathematical term describing a subtle procedure where algebraic structures controlling topology in some small dimension D are lifted to more sophisticated algebraic structures that control topology in dimension D+1, thus one dimension up. One of the structured developed in the proposal was a lifting of the so-called quantum group state sum models. In these models one starts with a network of a graph embedded in plane, which evaluates to a polynomial expression, via local interactions that can be described using linear algebra. These structures relat to two-dimensional models of statistical mechanics.

One of the constructions resulted from the proposal was a novel understanding of a higher-dimensional analogue of these state sums. The higher-dimensional analogue, known as foam evaluation, is due to L.-H.Robert and E.Wagner. In their construction, graph in the plane is replaced by a foam embedded in three space. The foam has singularities which are edges and vertices at which facets of the foam meet. In the model one labels facets of the foam into collections of colors, based on special rules, so that any two colors give rise to a surface inside the foam. This surface has the so-called Euler characteristic, related to the number of handles in it (sphere has no handles, while surface of a donut has one handle, for instance), which goes into the expression for the sum in the model. The sum is over all possible color labellings.

The resulting theory has several applications, including to consructing link homology invariants of knots and links. These invariants are vector spaces, as opposed to more conventional invariants of links, that are numbers. Work supported by this award further extended these foam models and related them to analytical constructions from the gauge theory that have been at the forefront of research in low-dimensional topology for the past several decades. This work contributes to the interactions and unification of analytical and algebro-combinatorial methods in low-dimensional topology that has been going on in the last several years.

Another paper based on this award hints at a far-reaching generalization of linear algebra. Linear algebra objects are vector spaces, each one of a certain dimension. The dimension is the number of vectors in a basis of the vector space. In mathematical language, linear algebra can be described as categorification of natural numbers, where a natural number gets upgraded to a vector space of that dimension, and operations on natural numbers, such as addition and multiplication, are lifted to operations on vector spaces, called direct sum and tensor product, correspondingly. Linear algebra is of fundamental value in much of science. There is a similar lifting of integers to  complexes of vector spaces, where subtraction operation of integers is lifted to forming the cone of complexes, and one recovers an integer from the complex by forming the homology and its Euler characteristic.

Beyond integers, it's common to consider rational numbers, where division by a nonzero number is posssible. One of the papers supported by the award explores far-reaching possible generalizations of linear algebra, where generalized complexes have the possibility of categorical division by a natural number. In particular, the paper presents a concrete model where division by two is possible. One can think of objects in that system as generalized vector spaces whose dimension is a rational number that may contain a power of two in the denominator rather than only a natural number. It appears to be the first such example in the literature, and there's expectation that some structures of this kind will naturally appear in mathematics and mathematical physics rather than being constructed in an artificial way.
